article:
'Enterprises in the Soviet Union' were legal entities engaged in some kind of
economic activity: production, distribution, services, and other kinds of
economic activity. An enterprise was the general equivalent of the legal entity
of "company" prominent outside of the Eastern-bloc economies. Enterprises and
production units engaged in economic activities that are generally undertaken by
business-enterprises in capitalist systems.

An enterprise often included production units, or associations of production
units called "Production associations", organized around the production and
distribution of a single sector or product. An example of a production
association was the Kazan Aircraft Production Association.

With the exception of the brief period of New Economic Policy, the Kosygin
reform and the final period of [[perestroika]] before the dissolution of the
Soviet Union, the terms company, business, corporation, etc., were considered to
be attributes of capitalism and were inapplicable to the Soviet socialist
economy, and there was virtually no private enterprise in the Soviet Union
during most of its history. The official term for economic units was
